column9: to start doing something with energy and determination.
column10: Here's a new premium episode for you to get stuck into.
column11: It's time to get stuck into the gardening.
column12: She got stuck into her homework as soon as she got home.

column9: a type of comedy performance in which a single person stands on a stage and tells jokes to an audience.
column10: ...we listened to a stand-up comedy routine by Paul Chowdhry.
column11: He's a famous stand-up comedian.
column12: I went to a stand-up comedy show last night.

column9: to not do or talk about something that you would normally do or talk about.
column10: I kind of skipped over the language bits.
column11: She skipped over the boring parts of the book.
column12: Let's skip over the next chapter for now.

column9: very hot.
column10: It is baking! I am baking Dave!
column11: It's baking hot outside.
column12: I'm absolutely baking in this room.

column9: very hot.
column10: It's roasting in here.
column11: I was absolutely roasting in bed last night.
column12: Can you open a window? It's roasting.

column9: very hot.
column10: It's boiling in here! I am absolutely boiling in this jacket!
column11: It was a boiling hot day.
column12: I'm boiling, can we turn on the air conditioning?

column9: uncomfortably hot.
column10: I am absolutely sweltering mate!
column11: It was a sweltering summer afternoon.
column12: How do you deal with sweltering hot conditions?

column9: very cold.
column10: I'm freezing cold.
column11: It's freezing outside.
column12: I'm absolutely freezing, can you close the window?

column9: adjectives that can have different degrees, used with adverbs like 'very' or 'a bit'.
column10: Basically this means you can use words like very and a bit. For example, tired is gradable.
column11: 'Hot' is a gradable adjective; you can say 'very hot'.
column12: Gradable adjectives can be used in comparative and superlative forms.

column9: adjectives that express absolute concepts and cannot be graded; used with adverbs like 'absolutely' or 'completely'.
column10: Exhausted is an example of a non-gradable or extreme adjective.
column11: We can't say 'very exhausted' but instead we use adverbs like 'absolutely'.
column12: 'Freezing' is a non-gradable adjective.

column9: producing liquid from your skin because you are hot; perspiring.
column10: I'm sweating like a right slag!
column11: I'm sweating like a pig.
column12: The sweat was pouring off me.

column9: (of a liquid) flowing in a thin line.
column10: I could feel the sweat trickling down the back of my neck.
column11: Tears were trickling down her cheeks.
column12: Rain was trickling down the windowpane.

column9: a particular way of speaking or using words, especially a way common to those with a particular job or interest.
column10: In common parlance this expression is used.
column11: In military parlance, this is known as a 'friendly fire' incident.
column12: The term has entered common parlance.

column9: a very offensive word for a woman who has a lot of sexual partners. Can be used as a general insult by some speakers.
column10: I'm sweating like a right slag!
column11: If you call a woman a slag it means she is promiscuous.
column12: Cockneys use 'slag' as an insult for anyone.

column9: to leave the place where you are living and go to live somewhere else.
column10: When are you going to move out and get yourself a job?
column11: My flatmate is moving out next month.
column12: I moved out of my parents' house when I was 18.

column9: to start living in a new place.
column10: My wife and I first moved in together when I moved to Paris.
column11: You can move in if you like.
column12: We're moving into our new flat next week.

column9: to get things, especially money or food, by asking people for them instead of buying or earning them.
column10: ...you scroungy little slag?
column11: Dave is so annoying. He's always scrounging money off everyone.
column12: Can I scrounge a cigarette off you mate?

column9: dirty and unpleasant; relating to a person who scrounges.
column10: ...you scroungy little slag?
column11: I get a lot of scroungy little stray cats hanging around my back door.
column12: He was wearing a scroungy old coat.

column9: the use of legal methods to pay as little tax as possible.
column10: ...the tax avoidance and tax evasion by corporations.
column11: Tax avoidance is legal, but many people consider it unethical.
column12: The government is cracking down on tax avoidance schemes.

column9: the illegal non-payment or underpayment of tax.
column10: ...the tax avoidance and tax evasion by corporations.
column11: He was arrested for tax evasion.
column12: Tax evasion is a serious crime.

column9: to accuse someone of being responsible for something bad.
column10: ...point the finger at poor, sick or disabled people.
column11: Don't point the finger at me, it wasn't my fault.
column12: The report points the finger at the company's management for the disaster.

column9: cats that have no home or have been lost.
column10: I get a lot of scroungy little stray cats hanging around my back door.
column11: She feeds the stray cats in her neighbourhood.
column12: The shelter is full of stray cats and dogs.

column9: an illness in which the body's solid waste is more liquid than usual and comes out of the body more often.
column10: I've got diarrhoea. I keep having to go to the toilet.
column11: That curry went right through me and gave me diarrhoea.
column12: Food poisoning can cause vomiting and diarrhoea.

column9: to take a day off work when you are not really ill.
column10: ...make up an excuse for your boss in order to pull a sickie at work.
column11: He pulled a sickie to go to the football match.
column12: I'm tempted to pull a sickie tomorrow.

column9: to accept or allow behaviour that is wrong.
column10: I don't condone that by the way.
column11: The school does not condone bullying.
column12: I cannot condone that kind of behaviour.

column9: the solid waste substance that people and animals get rid of from their bodies by passing it through the anus.
column10: ...when your faeces come out liquid because you're ill.
column11: The doctor asked for a stool sample to check for faeces.
column12: My faeces is runny/liquid.

column9: an upset stomach, especially one that causes diarrhoea.
column10: I've got a gippy tummy.
column11: I think I've got a bit of a gippy tummy from that curry last night.
column12: A lot of tourists get a gippy tummy when they travel.

column9: an upset stomach.
column10: I've got a dodgy stomach.
column11: I think I ate something dodgy.
column12: I've had a dodgy stomach all day.

column9: an illness affecting the stomach, usually causing vomiting and diarrhoea.
column10: I've got a stomach bug.
column11: The whole family came down with a stomach bug.
column12: Can you give someone a stomach bug over the internet?

column9: inflammation of the stomach and intestines, typically resulting from bacterial toxins or viral infection and causing vomiting and diarrhoea.
column10: I've got gastro (an abbreviation of gastroenteritis).
column11: Gastroenteritis is a common illness, especially in children.
column12: He was off work with a bout of gastroenteritis.

column9: the use of irony to mock or convey contempt.
column10: ...it's absolutely lovely - that's sarcasm folks.
column11: 'You've been a great help,' she said with heavy sarcasm.
column12: He has a very dry sense of humour and a talent for sarcasm.

column9: offensively rude or coarse, especially in relation to sexual matters.
column10: It's coming out of both ends - ooh this is a crude way to say it.
column11: He told a crude joke.
column12: I was shocked by his crude language.

column9: more liquid than usual.
column10: My poos are runny.
column11: I've got a runny nose.
column12: The cheese sauce was a bit runny.

column9: pieces of solid waste from the body.
column10: My stools are liquid.
column11: The doctor asked for a stool sample.
column12: How are your stools at the moment?

column9: a mild or indirect word or expression substituted for one considered to be too harsh or blunt when referring to something unpleasant or embarrassing.
column10: To do a number 2 is a euphemism for doing a poo.
column11: 'Passed away' is a euphemism for 'died'.
column12: He used a euphemism to avoid saying the rude word.

column9: (of food) to pass through the digestive system very quickly, causing diarrhoea.
column10: That curry went right through me.
column11: That spicy food went right through me.
column12: It's going / It's gone right through me Dave.

column9: a toilet.
column10: I've got to be on the shitter while I'm eating this.
column11: The shitter is a slang word for the toilet.
column12: Where's the shitter? I need to go.

column9: diarrhoea.
column10: I've got the shits.
column11: That curry gives them the shits.
column12: I think I've got the shits from that dodgy kebab.

column9: to bring food up from the stomach through the mouth.
column10: All of the following words mean to vomit.
column11: He started to vomit uncontrollably.
column12: The sick child had been vomiting all night.

column9: to vomit.
column10: I feel like I'm going to be sick.
column11: I think I'm going to be sick.
column12: She was sick three times in the night.

column9: to vomit.
column10: I think I'm going to throw up.
column11: He threw up all over the new carpet.
column12: The baby threw up her milk.

column9: to vomit.
column10: I feel like I'm going to puke.
column11: He puked up his dinner.
column12: The smell was so bad it made me want to puke.

column9: the feeling that you are going to vomit.
column10: I've got nausea.
column11: Symptoms of the illness include fever, headache, and nausea.
column12: She was overcome with nausea.

column9: feeling as if you are going to vomit.
column10: I'm feeling nauseous.
column11: The smell of the paint made her feel nauseous.
column12: I felt a bit nauseous after the boat trip.

column9: having lost too much water from your body.
column10: OK, you're probably dehydrated.
column11: It's important to drink plenty of water to avoid getting dehydrated.
column12: The doctor said he was severely dehydrated.

column9: a type of shellfish with a long tail and a thin shell.
column10: Yeah, but this one had prawns on it.
column11: I had a delicious prawn curry for dinner.
column12: Prawns on a pizza? Ew.

column9: a rise in the pitch of the voice at the end of a sentence, often used in questions.
column10: Yeah, hello Tony this is Luke (upward intonation).
column11: She spoke with a questioning upward intonation.
column12: Upward intonation can indicate uncertainty.

column9: a person from the East End of London; the dialect or accent of this person.
column10: I've become a cockney.
column11: He has a strong cockney accent.
column12: She's a true cockney, born and bred in the East End.

column9: the act of getting rid of solid waste from the body.
column10: How many times per day do you have a bowel movement at the moment?
column11: Regular bowel movements are a sign of a healthy digestive system.
column12: He was having difficulty with his bowel movements.

column9: a substance that helps you to have a bowel movement.
column10: Indian food is the only food that's referred to as a laxative.
column11: If you've got constipation, you might take a laxative.
column12: Some fruits have a natural laxative effect.

column9: the condition of being unable to get rid of solid waste from the body easily.
column10: Constipation is the opposite of diarrhea.
column11: A diet high in fiber can help to prevent constipation.
column12: He's been suffering from constipation for a few days.

column9: the long tube that carries solid waste from the stomach out of the body.
column10: ...it helps to 'loosen your bowels'.
column11: To empty your bowels.
column12: He has a problem with his bowels.

column9: the opening at the end of the alimentary canal through which solid waste matter leaves the body.
column10: ...between your stomach and your anus (bum hole).
column11: The doctor performed an examination of the patient's anus.
column12: He had a pain in his anus.

column9: trousers that stop at the knee.
column10: I may have emptied my bowels into my trousers (into my breeches).
column11: He was wearing a pair of old-fashioned breeches.
column12: The soldiers wore red coats and white breeches.

column9: for a very short time.
column10: Would you point me in the direction of the nearest water closet, please? I may be excused momentarily.
column11: He was momentarily stunned by the news.
column12: The train will be stopping momentarily at the next station.

column9: a toilet.
column10: Would you point me in the direction of the nearest water closet, please?
column11: The abbreviation 'W.C.' stands for water closet.
column12: The house has two bathrooms, each with a water closet.

column9: pain that you get in your stomach when you have difficulty digesting food.
column10: I've got indigestion.
column11: I get indigestion if I eat too quickly.
column12: He was suffering from a bout of indigestion.

column9: a burning feeling in your chest caused by indigestion.
column10: I've got heartburn.
column11: Spicy food gives me heartburn.
column12: He took some medicine for his heartburn.

column9: swollen with fluid or gas.
column10: I'm feeling bloated.
column11: I feel bloated after that big meal.
column12: Her stomach was bloated.

column9: to think or believe.
column10: I reckon we can all break down racial barriers.
column11: I reckon it's going to rain.
column12: What do you reckon?

column9: to improve understanding and communication between people who have different opinions.
column10: I reckon we can all break down racial barriers.
column11: Sport can help to break down barriers between people.
column12: International schools are helping to break down barriers between nations.

column9: to speak with an accent that is not your normal one.
column10: ...if we put on the accent of the person we're talking to.
column11: Could you put on a slight American accent for this role?
column12: She's not really from Texas, she's just putting on the accent.

column9: nervous or uncomfortable because you are worried about what people think about you or your actions.
column10: We feel ridiculous or self-conscious.
column11: He's very self-conscious about his height.
column12: She was a shy, self-conscious teenager.

column9: to accept a situation or a suggestion without arguing.
column10: Don't worry about your identity too much, just go with it.
column11: It wasn't the plan, but we decided to go with it.
column12: Sometimes you just have to go with it and see what happens.

column9: to copy the way another person speaks or behaves in order to be funny.
column10: Do an impression. You'll be surprised at how effective it can be.
column11: He does a great impression of the prime minister.
column12: Can you do an impression of a cat?

column9: used to show a result or consequence of a quality.
column10: I want him to get so angry that he takes it out on the guy in the kitchen.
column11: This soup is so hot that I can't drink it.
column12: I was so tired that I fell asleep as soon as my head touched the pillow.

column9: to treat someone badly because you are angry or upset, even though it is not their fault.
column10: I want him to get so angry that he takes it out on the guy in the kitchen.
column11: I know you're stressed, but don't take it out on me.
column12: Sorry I had a bad day and I was just taking it out on you.

column9: providing psychological relief through the open expression of strong emotions.
column10: That's quite satisfying and cathartic.
column11: Crying can be a cathartic experience.
column12: It was a cathartic to talk about his feelings.

column9: a way of forming the passive voice, often more informal than using 'be'.
column10: Someone is getting Jackie Channed in that kitchen.
column11: I got caught in the rain.
column12: He got fired from his job.

column9: having no money.
column10: That's when you know you're skint.
column11: I'm a bit skint at the moment.
column12: I can't go out tonight, I'm skint.

column9: having no money.
column10: Other similar words might be broke or hard up.
column11: I'm a bit broke at the moment.
column12: I'm always broke by the end of the month.

column9: having very little money.
column10: I can't come out this evening, I'm a bit hard up.
column11: We were very hard up when we were students.
column12: She was too hard up to buy a new coat.

column9: not generous, especially with money.
column10: Neil is so stingy. He never buys anyone else a pint.
column11: He's too stingy to pay for a taxi.
column12: Don't be so stingy!

column9: to spend a lot of money on buying things, especially things that are pleasant but not essential.
column10: I splashed out on a load of new clothes this afternoon.
column11: She splashed out on a new car.
column12: We're going to splash out and go to a fancy restaurant for our anniversary.

column9: wet and soft, usually in a way that is unpleasant.
column10: I've got soggy chips!
column11: The ground was all soggy from the rain.
column12: My socks are soggy.

column9: slightly wet, especially in a way that is not pleasant or comfortable.
column10: These towels still aren't dry. They're still a bit damp.
column11: The clothes are still damp.
column12: It was a damp, cold day.

column9: slightly wet, especially in a good way.
column10: This cake is lovely. How did you make it so moist?
column11: The soil should be moist before you plant something.
column12: Keep the soil in the pot moist, but not wet.

column9: extremely wet.
column10: I got caught in the rain and when I arrived I was absolutely soaking.
column11: My clothes are soaking wet.
column12: We got soaking in the storm.

column9: completely wet.
column10: I got completely drenched in the rain.
column11: We were drenched to the skin.
column12: A sudden downpour drenched the spectators.

column9: so wet that drops of water are falling from you.
column10: When he arrived home he was dripping wet.
column11: Her hair was dripping wet.
column12: He came in from the rain, dripping wet.

column9: completely wet.
column10: I was so hot that my t-shirt was saturated with sweat.
column11: The ground was saturated after the heavy rain.
column12: The towel was saturated with water.

column9: (of snow or ice) partly melted.
column10: The ground is all slushy.
column11: The streets were covered in brown, slushy snow.
column12: It's disgusting out there. The snow is melting and the ground is all slushy.

column9: (of land) so full of water that it cannot hold any more.
column10: The football pitch was completely waterlogged.
column11: The heavy rain had left the fields waterlogged.
column12: We've got a waterlogged field that needs draining.

column9: having a layer of something on the surface.
column10: The floor in the kitchen is totally covered in water.
column11: The car was covered in mud.
column12: He was covered in bruises after the fight.

column9: containing a lot of something.
column10: This plant pot is full of water.
column11: The box was full of old photographs.
column12: She is a person full of energy and enthusiasm.

column9: to cancel something.
column10: ...so we had to call off the game.
column11: The match was called off because of the bad weather.
column12: They called off the wedding at the last minute.

column9: likely to be dishonest or unreliable; not working properly.
column10: I think I ate something dodgy.
column11: He was involved in a dodgy business deal.
column12: The brakes on my car feel a bit dodgy.

column9: hard but liable to break easily.
column10: Pig iron is a basic, crude form of iron which is not very strong. It's brittle.
column11: As you get older your bones become more brittle.
column12: The plastic had become brittle with age.
